qas.question: Why did the Somers Isles Company decide to surpress shipbuilding?

answers.text: needed Bermudians to farm to generate income from the land
colony of Virginia far surpassed Bermuda in both quality and quantity of tobacco produced

qas.question: What did Bermudians do when agriculture failed?
Why was the Somers Isles Company's charter revoked?
What did the Somers Isles Company press in the 17th century?
What colony did Bermuda surpass in quantity of tobacco produced?
What colony did Bermuda surpass in quality of tobacco produced?

context: In the 17th century, the Somers Isles Company suppressed <b4_0>shipbuilding<b4_0/>, as it <a0_0>needed Bermudians to farm to generate income from the land<a0_0/>. Agricultural production met with limited success, however. The Bermuda cedar boxes used to ship tobacco to England were reportedly worth more than their contents.[citation needed] The <a1_0>colony of <b5_0><b6_0>Virginia<b6_0/><b5_0/> far surpassed Bermuda in both quality and quantity of tobacco produced<a1_0/>. Bermudians began to <a2_0>turn to maritime trades<a2_0/> relatively early in the 17th century, but the <b7_0>Somers Isles Company<b7_0/> used all its authority to suppress turning away from agriculture. This interference led to the <a3_0>islanders demanding<a3_0/>, and receiving, the revocation of the Company's charter in 1684, and the Company was dissolved.
